title: Eliud Kipchoge delighted after finally shattering two-hour marathon by 20 SECONDS in Vienna
text:
Eliud Kipchoge was delighted to make history after becoming the first man to run a marathon in under two hours and likened his achievement to Roger Bannister's four minute mile.

The 34-year-old ran an incredible one hour, 59 minutes and 40 seconds in Vienna, smashing the two-hour barrier at the second attempt after trying and failing in Monza in 2017.

The Kenyan missed the two-marathon by 26 seconds in that previous attempt, but bettered that effort this time round by a staggering 46 seconds, cuing jubilant scenes in the Austrian capital.

Eliud Kipchoge became the first man to break the two-hour marathon barrier in Vienna

After finally achieving the historic target, the runner was keen to draw comparisons with Sir Roger Bannister's historic sub four-minute mile in 1954.

After the race, Kipchoge told the BBC: 'I am feeling good. It has taken 65 years for a human to make history in sport.

'After Roger Bannister it took another 65 years … I'm happy to be the man to run under two hours.

'No human is limited, and I'm expecting more people to do it after today.

Former athlete Sir Roger Bannister became the first man to run a sub four-minute mile in 1954

Kipchoge was racing alone but was assisted by 41 pacemakers, including former Olympic and world record holders, in his attempt to achieve the milestone.

'The 41 pacemakers are among the best athletes in the whole world … to all of them I want to say thank you, thank you for doing the job. We made history together.'
description: Eliud Kipchoge was delighted to make history after becoming the first man to run a marathon in under two hours and likened his achievement to Roger Bannister's four minute mile.
